fields.descriptive_line: Photograph of the interior courtyard of the Jami Masjid at Fatephur Sikri, Agra, India, by Samuel Bourne, ca.1865.
fields.physical_description:
This photograph shows the inside of the Jami Masjid, the principle building of Fatehpur Sikri. It comprises an open courtyard  surrounded  with pillared  cloisters on three sides. In the photograph the building on the right hand side is the Jamaat Khana (Tomb of Islam Khan) and in the middle is Shaikh Salim Chishti’s white marble tomb. On the left hand side of the courtyard, the western end is dominated by an iwan (large arched recess) containing the entrance to the central prayer chamber. The great dome of the prayer chamber is just visible behind the iwan. 

There are several figures in the courtyard which indicate the great scale of the building. There are also some trees which are no longer on the site.
fields.dimensions: Length: 30.7 cm photograph, Height: 18.4 cm photograph, Length: 32.4 cm mount, Height: 26.4 cm mount
fields.title: Interior of the Great Quadrangle, showing Sheik Selim Chisti's tomb, Futtehpore Sikri.
fields.materials_techniques: Albumen print from a wet collodion negative

fields.name: South and South East Asian Collection

fields.marks: Signature and negative number in bottom right hand side.
fields.public_access_description:
This photograph shows the interior of the courtyard of the Jami Masjid. This mosque is the principle building of Fatehpur Sikri, a city built by the Mughal Emperor Akbar (ruled 1556-1605). According to an inscription inside the masjid, the construction of the building was completed bewteen 1571 and 1572. 

The open courtyard has pillared cloisters on three sides. The building on the right-hand side is the Jamaat Khana (Tomb of Islam Khan) and in the middle is the white marble tomb of Salim Chishti, a Sufi saint. 

The British photographer Samuel Bourne lived and worked in India between 1862 and 1869. During this time he toured the Himalayas and travelled through the subcontinent, photographing its landscape, architecture and historical sites. He set up a studio in Simla with Charles Shepherd and sold his prints sold to an eager public both in India and Britain.
fields.bibliography:
Alfieri, B.M, Islamic Architecture of the Indian Subcontinent, London 2000,
Archaeological Survey of India, Fatehpur Sikri, New Delhi, 2002

Asher, C, B, Architecture of Mughal India, The New Cambridhe History of India, , CUP, 1992
fields.history_note:
This photograph was initially part of the photographic collection held in the National Art Library. The markings on the mount are an indication of the history of the object, its movement through the museum and the way it is categorised.
This window mount is similar to others in the collection. At one point it would also have had a label with red edging indicating the title of the photograph. There is evidence of this being torn off the mount. This type of label and mount suggests inclusion in an exhibition, possibly the Paris exhibition of 1867 or the subsequent South Kensington exhibition for which no catalogue has been found.

Historical significance: This photograph shows the inside of the Jami Masjid, the principle building of Fatehpur Sikri. It comprises an open courtyard or shan which measures 130m by 165m and is surrounded  with pillared  cloisters on three sides. In the photograph the building on the right hand side is the Jamaat Khana (Tomb of Islam Khan) and in the middle is Shaikh Salim Chishti’s white marble tomb. On the left hand side of the courtyard, the western end is dominated by an iwan (large arched recess) containing the entrance to the central prayer chamber. The great dome of the prayer chamber is just visible behind the iwan. The archway of the iwan is 14.63 meters high

Northern and Eastern cells were intended to accommodate the Shaikhs senior disciples – where they performed their devotional exercises. 

There are several figures in the courtyard which indicate the great scale of the building. There are also some trees which are no longer on the site.
